This is a list of records of the [FIFA World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA
World Cup") and its [qualification matches](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_qualification
"FIFA World Cup qualification").  
See also: [National team appearances in the FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/National_team_appearances_in_the_FIFA_World_Cup "National team
appearances in the FIFA World Cup").

  12. **Jump up ^** According to the [Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation](/wiki/Rec.Sport.Soccer_Statistics_Foundation "Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation"),[8] [Fuad Anwar Amin](/wiki/Fuad_Anwar_Amin "Fuad Anwar Amin") of ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Flag_of_Saudi_Arabia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Saudi_Arabia.svg.png) [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_national_football_team "Saudi Arabia national football team") would have been the youngest captain, at 21 years & 250 days in the [1994](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994 FIFA World Cup"), but the source does not specify the match in which he was captain. It is listed that the starting captain was substituted in both the match against the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team "Netherlands national football team") and the one against [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden_national_football_team "Sweden national football team"), in which Amin may have been given the armband on the captains' substitutions, but this information has not been verified. In any case, Meola still is the youngest _starting_ captain, and players who received the captain's armband during the course of the match are generally not regarded as _official_ captains.

and likewise ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/23px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png) [Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national football team") between 0–3 v ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Flag_of_Croatia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Croatia.svg.png) [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia_national_football_team "Croatia national football team") in [1998](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup "1998 FIFA World Cup") and 8–0 v ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Flag_of_Saudi_Arabia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Saudi_Arabia.svg.png) [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_national_football_team "Saudi Arabia national football team") in [2002](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup").

  55. **Jump up ^** Switzerland's best position, the sixth place in 1950, relies on retrospective rankings, and had them eliminated in the group stage. While the Swiss also reached the quarter-finals in 1934 and 1938, both tournaments only required one win, in contrast to 1954's group stage format. 1954 also marked the last time Switzerland reached the top 8.
  56. **Jump up ^** Not counting the results as ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union_%281955%E2%80%931980%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union_%281955%E2%80%931980%29.svg.png) [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union_national_football_team "Soviet Union national football team"), who reached the semi-finals in 1966.

  58. **Jump up ^** 2010 had hosts South Africa matching their 2002 record, falling in the group stage with one win, one tie and one draw, even if with a lower goal difference.
  59. **Jump up ^** Although the decisive match of the 1950 tournament, it was simply the last game of a final four-team group format to decide the winner. This is also the highest attendance for ANY World Cup match, or indeed any soccer match anywhere.
